questions.question: Which of the following IEEE 802.11 amendments introduced MU-MIMO for the first time?
What is the maximum theoretical data rate for a single spatial stream using 802.11ax with 160 MHz channel width and 1024-QAM?
Which WiFi security protocol uses a four-way handshake to establish a secure connection between client and access point?
In an 802.11ax network, which feature allows access points to coordinate transmissions to avoid collisions?
What is the purpose of the Association Identifier (AID) in the 802.11 MAC layer?
options: Identifies the physical location of a client
Defines the priority of traffic classes
Uniquely identifies a client in a BSS for data delivery
Serves as the encryption key for WPA2
questions.answer: Uniquely identifies a client in a BSS for data delivery

questions.question: Which frame subtype is used in the 802.11 standard to respond to a Probe Request?
What is the role of the RADIUS server in an 802.1X authentication process?
options: Encrypts the data between client and access point
Provides dynamic frequency selection (DFS) for 5 GHz channels
Configures QoS settings for the network

questions.question: Which of the following is a characteristic of the 5 GHz band compared to the 2.4 GHz band in WiFi networks?
options: Longer range but lower data rates
More prone to interference from microwave ovens

questions.question: In 802.11 networks, which field in the MAC header is used to manage frame retransmission?
What is the function of the RTS/CTS mechanism in WiFi communication?
options: To enable multi-user communication in OFDMA
To provide encryption during the transmission of frames
To mitigate the hidden node problem
To adjust the transmission power for better range
questions.answer: To mitigate the hidden node problem

questions.question: Which modulation technique is used in 802.11ax to achieve higher data rates?
What is the maximum number of spatial streams supported in 802.11ac?
Which protocol is responsible for mapping MAC addresses to IP addresses in a wireless network?
Which 802.11 standard first introduced the concept of MIMO (Multiple Input Multiple Output)?
What is the primary purpose of Dynamic Frequency Selection (DFS) in 5 GHz WiFi networks?
options: To balance load between access points

questions.question: Which type of antenna is typically used for long-range point-to-point wireless links?
What is the maximum EIRP allowed for WiFi transmission in the 2.4 GHz band in the United States?
Which of the following methods is used for detecting WiFi network congestion in 802.11ax?
In WiFi, what is the purpose of the preamble in a data frame?
options: To synchronize the receiver with the transmitter
questions.answer: To synchronize the receiver with the transmitter

questions.question: Which of the following is a WiFi Alliance certification program focused on improving video streaming quality?
What is the channel width of a single channel in the 2.4 GHz band?
What is the typical backoff method used in CSMA/CA to manage channel access in WiFi networks?
Which 802.11 amendment introduced Fast BSS Transition (FT) for improved handoff between access points?
What is the purpose of the NAV (Network Allocation Vector) in 802.11 MAC operation?
options: To allocate bandwidth for data streams
To indicate the time period during which the medium is occupied
questions.answer: To indicate the time period during which the medium is occupied

questions.question: Which of the following is an advantage of using OFDMA in 802.11ax?
What is the primary difference between WPA2 and WPA3 security protocols?
options: WPA3 introduces the Simultaneous Authentication of Equals (SAE)
questions.answer: WPA3 introduces the Simultaneous Authentication of Equals (SAE)

questions.question: Which of the following tools is most commonly used for WiFi packet capture and analysis?
What is the primary function of the TIM (Traffic Indication Map) in a WiFi beacon frame?
options: Indicates the data rate supported by the AP
Signals the presence of buffered data for clients
questions.answer: Signals the presence of buffered data for clients

questions.question: Which frequency band does WiFi 6E operate in?
Which of the following is a feature of Target Wake Time (TWT) in 802.11ax?
options: Enables multiple devices to transmit simultaneously
Allows devices to schedule their wake-up times
questions.answer: Allows devices to schedule their wake-up times

questions.question: Which type of WiFi interference is most likely to be caused by a microwave oven?
In a WiFi network, what is the purpose of the 'Ack' frame?
options: To acknowledge receipt of a data frame
To request association with an AP
questions.answer: To acknowledge receipt of a data frame

questions.question: What is the minimum signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) typically required for a stable 802.11ac connection?
Which wireless feature is designed to allow devices to operate in environments with overlapping access points without significant interference?
What is the role of the Group Temporal Key (GTK) in WPA2?
options: Encrypts unicast traffic between client and AP
Performs mutual authentication between client and AP

questions.question: What does the 'greenfield' mode refer to in 802.11n?
Which 802.11 standard first introduced support for Quality of Service (QoS) through EDCA?
In WiFi networks, what is an SSID?
Which 802.11 standard operates exclusively in the 60 GHz frequency band?
What does the term 'hidden node' refer to in WiFi?
options: A device with a weak signal
A device that cannot detect another device's transmission
An AP with a hidden SSID
questions.answer: A device that cannot detect another device's transmission

questions.question: Which of the following is a key characteristic of WiFi Direct?
options: Requires an access point for communication
Supports peer-to-peer connections without an AP
questions.answer: Supports peer-to-peer connections without an AP

questions.question: Which frame type is used to disconnect a client from an access point in WiFi networks?
What is the role of a Supplicant in 802.1X authentication?
options: It acts as a network switch

questions.question: Which type of wireless interference is most commonly caused by nearby Bluetooth devices?
Which encryption method is used in WPA3 to protect data privacy?
What is the primary function of Beamforming in WiFi?
options: To improve battery life of client devices
To reduce interference from nearby APs
To focus the WiFi signal towards a specific client
To extend the frequency range of the AP
questions.answer: To focus the WiFi signal towards a specific client

questions.question: Which of the following technologies allows multiple clients to share the same frequency channel in 802.11ax?
Which of the following protocols is used for secure remote configuration of WiFi access points?
In WiFi networks, what does the term 'roaming' refer to?
options: Changing the SSID of an AP
A client moving between APs within the same ESS
Configuring a new client on the network
questions.answer: A client moving between APs within the same ESS

questions.question: Which WiFi standard includes the use of 80+80 MHz channels?
Which of the following is a characteristic of WEP that makes it insecure?
What is the purpose of the DHCP snooping feature in WiFi networks?
options: To enhance encryption between client and server
To assign IP addresses to clients

questions.question: What is the role of the 'acknowledgement' in the CSMA/CA protocol used in WiFi?
Which of the following is a common cause of WiFi channel interference?
What is the role of the PMK (Pairwise Master Key) in WPA2?
options: To encrypt data between client and AP
To generate transient keys for data encryption
questions.answer: To generate transient keys for data encryption

questions.question: Which of the following is a potential security risk when using an open WiFi network?
What is the purpose of RRM (Radio Resource Management) in enterprise WiFi deployments?
options: To increase the number of SSIDs
To manage power levels and channel selection
questions.answer: To manage power levels and channel selection

questions.question: Which type of frame in WiFi is used to maintain synchronization between an AP and its clients?
Which 802.11 feature allows a WiFi network to operate in a 'mesh' configuration, extending coverage without additional wired infrastructure?
What does the acronym 'DFS' stand for in WiFi networks?
Which of the following describes the effect of increasing channel width from 20 MHz to 40 MHz in a 2.4 GHz WiFi network?
options: Increases throughput but also increases interference risk
questions.answer: Increases throughput but also increases interference risk

questions.question: Which parameter is most important to adjust for improving the range of a WiFi access point?
What is a key limitation of using WMM (Wi-Fi Multimedia) for prioritizing traffic?
Which of the following is a critical factor for ensuring high-performance WiFi in dense environments?
options: Using a single SSID for all access points

questions.question: Which modulation scheme is least likely to be used in a modern 802.11ax network?
What is the role of the 'Control and Provisioning of Wireless Access Points' (CAPWAP) protocol?
options: Manages power levels of access points
Facilitates communication between wireless controllers and access points
questions.answer: Facilitates communication between wireless controllers and access points

questions.question: What is the recommended minimum RSSI for reliable video streaming over WiFi?
Which of the following could cause a WiFi signal to weaken as it passes through a wall?
What is the primary function of a WiFi bridge?
options: To extend the range of an SSID
To convert wired connections into wireless
To link two wired networks wirelessly
questions.answer: To link two wired networks wirelessly

questions.question: Which of the following can be used to measure the signal strength of a WiFi network?
What is a common method for mitigating co-channel interference in WiFi deployments?
Which type of attack is specifically aimed at causing a denial of service in a WiFi network?
What is the maximum theoretical data rate for a 160 MHz channel in 802.11ac?
Which WiFi standard first introduced the concept of 'Guard Interval' to reduce inter-symbol interference?
Which of the following WiFi technologies is most effective at minimizing the impact of multipath fading?
What is the role of a WiFi repeater?
options: To extend WiFi coverage by amplifying signals
To act as a DHCP server
questions.answer: To extend WiFi coverage by amplifying signals

questions.question: What is the primary difference between open system authentication and shared key authentication in WEP?
options: Shared key does not require a password
Open system does not encrypt the authentication frame
Shared key is faster than open system
questions.answer: Open system does not encrypt the authentication frame

questions.question: Which of the following features is exclusive to WiFi 6 (802.11ax)?
Which layer of the OSI model does the 802.11 MAC sublayer operate at?
What is the primary purpose of a WiFi heatmap?
options: To visualize signal strength across an area
questions.answer: To visualize signal strength across an area

questions.question: Which type of network topology is used when multiple access points communicate with a single wireless controller?
Which of the following is a method for increasing the throughput of a WiFi network without adding new access points?
What is the main function of WiFi Protected Setup (WPS)?
options: To simplify the process of connecting devices
questions.answer: To simplify the process of connecting devices

questions.question: Which WiFi standard supports data rates up to 54 Mbps in the 2.4 GHz band?
Which term describes the reduction in signal strength as a wireless signal travels through the air?
Which wireless standard is known for operating in the 900 MHz ISM band, often used in industrial IoT applications?
